text: Hold thou me up, and I shall be safe: and I will have respect unto thy statutes continually.
text_kjv: Hold thou me up, and I shall be safe: and I will have respect unto thy statutes continually.
text_niv: Uphold me, and I will be delivered;I will always have regard for your decrees.
text_esv: Hold me up, that I may be safe and have regard for your statutes continually!
text_nlt: Sustain me, and I will be rescued;then I will meditate continually on your decrees.
text_msg: Stick with me and I'll be all right;I'll give total allegiance to your definitions of life.
text_nasb: Uphold me that I may be safe, That I may have regard for Your statutes continually.
context: Psalm 119, the longest chapter in the Bible, is an acrostic poem extolling the virtues and benefits of God's law (Torah). Each of its 176 verses (divided into 22 stanzas of 8 verses each, corresponding to the 22 letters of the Hebrew alphabet) focuses on a different aspect of the law—statutes, precepts, commandments, testimonies, judgments, etc.—but all pointing to the same divine source and authority. Understanding the cultural context requires recognizing the immense value placed on Torah in ancient Israelite society. The law wasn't merely a set of rules; it was considered God's revealed will, a guide to righteous living, and a source of wisdom and blessing. Memorization and meditation on the Torah were central to spiritual growth. The psalmist's constant emphasis on the law's benefits reflects a deep understanding of its role in shaping character, providing guidance, and fostering a close relationship with God. To 'have respect' in the ancient world, particularly toward laws or figures of authority, meant to hold them in high regard, obey them diligently, and learn from them. The psalmist isn't just asking for physical safety, but for spiritual upholding that enables him to consistently obey and revere God's statutes. The repeated emphasis on 'continually' underlines the need for ongoing divine assistance and a commitment to lifelong obedience. Without God's constant support, adherence to the law would be impossible due to human weakness and the allure of sin.
meaning: This verse reveals a profound understanding of human dependence on God for spiritual stability and obedience. The psalmist acknowledges his inherent weakness and inability to remain steadfast in following God's laws without divine intervention. The plea, 'Hold thou me up,' signifies a request for God's sustaining grace, a lifting up from the potential pitfalls of sin and temptation. It’s not a passive request, but an active dependence, an admission that self-reliance is insufficient. The promise, 'and I shall be safe,' suggests that true security lies not in personal strength or cleverness, but in God's unwavering support. This safety is not merely physical, but primarily spiritual – protection from the consequences of disobedience and a safeguarding of one's relationship with God. The phrase, 'and I will have respect unto thy statutes continually,' is a commitment born out of God's upholding power. It is not a precondition for God's help, but a consequence of it. The 'respect' here signifies more than just intellectual agreement; it's an active reverence, obedience, and joyful adherence to God's laws. 'Continually' underscores the ongoing nature of this commitment, highlighting the psalmist's desire for a lifelong relationship with God characterized by consistent obedience and reverence. This verse captures the essence of grace – divine assistance enabling human obedience, leading to true safety and a transformed heart that delights in God's law. It is a testament to the synergistic relationship between divine grace and human responsibility, where God's empowering presence enables and sustains our commitment to His will.
application: In our modern context, Psalm 119:117 serves as a powerful reminder of our constant need for God's grace and guidance. We live in a world filled with distractions and temptations that constantly pull us away from God's truth. The 'statutes' of God can be seen as principles taught through Scripture, the moral law written on our hearts, and the wisdom found in a relationship with Jesus. We cannot rely on our willpower or moral compass alone to navigate these challenges. We must actively seek God's help, asking Him to 'hold us up' – to strengthen our resolve, guard our hearts, and guide our steps. This is not a one-time prayer, but a daily, even hourly, dependence on God's sustaining power. This plea for God to hold us up should become a conscious decision to depend on Him in all situations; big or small. The promise to 'have respect unto thy statutes continually' translates into a commitment to diligently study God's Word, to actively apply its principles to our lives, and to consistently seek to align our thoughts, words, and actions with His will. This includes making time for prayer, engaging in fellowship with other believers, and seeking accountability for our choices. It's about cultivating a mindset of obedience and a desire to please God in every area of our lives. We must recognize that true safety and fulfillment are found not in worldly possessions or achievements, but in a close and obedient relationship with God. Continually seeking God’s guidance can lead us to making good decisions in careers, relationships, and spiritual life. We need the Lord’s continuous help and wisdom.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I come before you acknowledging my weakness and dependence on you. I confess that I often stumble and fall short of your perfect standard. I ask that you would 'hold me up,' that you would strengthen my resolve and guide my steps. Give me the grace to resist temptation and to choose the path of righteousness. Help me to have a deep and abiding respect for your Word and your ways. May my heart be filled with a desire to obey your statutes continually. Thank you for the safety and security that comes from trusting in you. I pray that you would fill me with wisdom to live a life that is pleasing to you. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: To 'have respect unto thy statutes' signifies more than just intellectual understanding or agreement with God's laws. It means to hold them in high regard, to revere them, to obey them willingly, and to seek to understand their deeper meaning. It reflects a heart that is devoted to God and desires to please Him.
faqs.question: Q1: What does it mean to 'have respect unto thy statutes'?

faqs.answer: Asking God to 'hold us up' acknowledges our inherent weakness and dependence on Him. We are constantly bombarded with temptations and distractions, and without God's grace and strength, we are likely to stumble and fall. It demonstrates humility and a recognition of our need for divine assistance.
faqs.question: Q2: Why is it important to ask God to 'hold us up'?

faqs.answer: Cultivating a desire to obey God's statutes involves immersing yourself in His Word, praying for understanding and guidance, and seeking fellowship with other believers who can encourage you in your faith. It also requires a conscious effort to align your thoughts, words, and actions with God's will.
faqs.question: Q3: How can I cultivate a desire to obey God's statutes continually?

faqs.answer: Practically, this verse can be applied by starting each day with prayer, asking for God's guidance and strength. Regularly read and meditate on Scripture, actively seek to obey God's commandments, and be accountable to fellow believers. Making small, conscious choices that please God throughout the day will help cultivate an environment of obedience.
faqs.question: Q4: What are some practical ways to apply this verse to my daily life?

faqs.answer: This verse beautifully illustrates the concept of grace. The psalmist acknowledges his inability to obey God's law on his own and asks for God's help. God's grace empowers us to obey Him, leading to true safety and a transformed heart that delights in His ways. Grace is the empowering presence.
